elements.content: Six novel complexes, namely, {[Zn1.5(L)(bix)1.5(H2O)]·H2O} n (1), {[Co1.5(L)(bix)1.5(H2O)]·H2O} n (2), {[Co3(L)2(4,4′-bpy)3]·5H2O} n (3), {[Cd3(L)2(4,4′-bpy)3]·4.5H2O} n (4), {[Cu3(L)2(4,4′-bpy)3]·3H2O} n (5), and {[Ni1.5(L)(4,4′-bpy)1.5(H2O)3]·2H2O} n (6) have been synthesized by the hydrothermal reaction of 5-(4-carboxy-2-nitrophenoxy)isophthalic acid (H3L) with different transition metal ions in the presence of ancillary ligands, 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bix) and 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bpy). Complexes 1 and 2 are isostructural, possessing a (3,8)-connected tfz-d type topology with the Schläfli symbol of {43}2{46·618·84}. The 3D structures of complexes 3–5 are very similar to complex 1 with only a little difference of the H3L coordination motif in complexes 4 and 5. Meanwhile, we use 4,4′-bpy instead of bix as the ancillary ligand in all three complexes. Complex 6 is a mixed one-dimensional chain and two-dimensional sheet structure, which are further linked to each other in a three-dimensional framework by H-bond interactions. All the complexes are characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, IR spectroscopy, thermogravimetry analysis, and elemental analysis. In addition, the luminescent properties of complexes 1 and 4 are discussed, and the magnetic properties of complexes 2 and 3 are also investigated.

elements.content: Six coordination polymers have been synthesized by the self-assembly of the V-shaped tricarboxylate ligands, neutral ligand, and metal ions and are structurally characterized. The three-dimensional structure of five complexes possess a (3,8)-connected tfz-d type topology with different trinuclear metal clusters, the sixth is a mixed one-dimensional chain and two-dimensional sheet structure.

elements.content: The rational design and synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or denoted as metal–organic coordination polymers have attracted considerable attention in recent years, owing to their fascinating nature of molecular connectivities and topologies, as well as potential applications in gas adsorption and separation, catalysis, photoactive materials, magnetism, ion exchange, and so on. Thus far, a large number of metal–organic coordination polymers have prepared. However, until now, it is still a challenge to control the final structures because of many factors, such as the coordination geometry of the central metal ions, connective modes of organic ligands, and the synthetic conditions, which have big influences on the resulting structures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rational design and synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) or denoted as metal-organic coordination polymers have attracted considerable attention in recent years, owing to their fascinating nature of molecular connectivities and topologies, as well as potential applications in gas adsorption and separation, catalysis, photoactive materials, magnetism, ion exchange, and so on. Thus far, a large number of metal-organic coordination polymers have prepared. However, until now, it is still a challenge to control the final structures because of many factors, such as the coordination geometry of the central metal ions, connective modes of organic ligands, and the synthetic conditions, which have big influences on the resulting structures.

elements.content: As is referred, organic ligands play important roles in directing the final structural properties. For constructing appropriate coordination polymers, the key factor is to design organic ligands which favor structure-specific self-assembly. Polycarboxylic acids, as a crucial family of multidentate O-donor ligands, have been extensively used due to their versatile coordination conformations and strong coordination ability. Up to now, plentiful research have been focused on the use of rigid carboxylate ligands, such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (p-H2BDC), 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (H2BPDC), and 1,3,5-tris(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene (H3BTB). MOFs built from the rigid carboxylate ligands generally exhibit exceptional porosity and surface area, which can be used in adsorption and separation processes. At the same time, a lot of intriguing metal–organic frameworks based on flexible carboxylate ligands, for instance, 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate and tetrahydrofurantetercarboxylate with flexible cores have also been extensively employed for the preparation of functional MOFs. Compared with rigid and flexible carboxylate ligands mentioned above, a semirigid V-shaped tricarboxylate ligand named 5-(4-carboxy-2-nitrophenoxy)isophthalic acid (H3L), featuring two benzene rings connected by a nonmetallic O atom, captured our attention. It could exhibit irregular orientations when connecting to metals, thereby affording abundant structural motifs. Furthermore, though the nitro group is not tangled in coordination, it may have an influence on the constructing processes, the structures, and even the properties of the MOFs, for considering its electronic and geometric effects. To the best of our knowledge, there are rarely MOFs assembled from the H3L ligand reported by our and other groups. Our group got a set of lanthanide coordination polymers, exhibiting the same three-dimensional (3D) architecture, which is built up from binuclear paddle-wheel building blocks. Liu and co-workers synthesized two novel Co metal–organic frameworks possessing 3-nodal networks with new topological prototypes. Gu and co-workers reported a fascinating Co polythreaded coordination network formed by a one-dimensional (1D) crankshaft-shaped chains, threading into a two-dimensional (2D) undulated sheet. With their work taken into account, there are still lots of opportunities worth exploring. Our work in this paper is not only the preparation of another two new Co 3D frameworks but also four different transitional metal 3D frameworks. In addition, the ancillary ligands containing N-donors have been used widely to extend the metal carboxylate system to a higher-dimensional network.

elements.content: Herein, we successfully obtained six new coordination polymers based on the semirigid V-shaped tricarboxylate ligand and the N-donor neutral ligands, namely, {[Zn1.5(L)(bix)1.5(H2O)]·H2O} n (1), {[Co1.5(L)(bix)1.5(H2O)]·H2O} n (2), {[Co3(L)2(4,4′-bpy)3]·5H2O} n (3), {[Cd3(L)2(4,4′-bpy)3]·4.5H2O} n (4), {[Cu3(L)2(4,4′-bpy)3]·3H2O} n (5), and {[Ni1.5(L)(4,4′-bpy)1.5(H2O)3]·2H2O} n (6). Their synthesis, crystal structures, and thermal properties were reported in this paper. In addition, the luminescent properties of complexes 1 and 4 were discussed, and the magnetic properties of complexes 2 and 3 were also investigated.

elements.content: The 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bix) was synthesized according to the literature.All of the starting materials employed were purchased from commercial sources and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses were determined with a VarioEL analyzer. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy were obtained with a Bruker TENSOR 27 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer with the KBr pellet technique and operating in the transmittance mode in the 4000–400 cm–1 region. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from room temperature to 700 °C under air (for complexes 1–4) and N2 (for complexes 5–6) atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were collected on a Bruker D8-ADVANCE diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα1 (λ = 1.5406 Å, 1600 W, 40 kV, 40 mA) at a scan speed of 5° min–1. The fluorescence excitation and emission spectra were recorded at room temperature with a Hitachi F-4500 spectrophotometer equipped with a 150 W xenon lamp as an excitation source. Temperature-dependent magnetic measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS-7 magnetometer with an applied field of 1000 Oe. The diamagnetic corrections for the complexes were estimated using Pascal’s constants and magnetic data were corrected for diamagnetic contributions of the sample holder.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

The 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bix) was synthesized according to the literature.All of the starting materials employed were purchased from commercial sources and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses were determined with a VarioEL analyzer. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy were obtained with a Bruker TENSOR 27 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer with the KBr pellet technique and operating in the transmittance mode in the 4000-400 cm-1 region. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from room temperature to 700 °C under air (for complexes 1-4) and N2 (for complexes 5-6) atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were collected on a Bruker D8-ADVANCE diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα1 (λ = 1.5406 Å, 1600 W, 40 kV, 40 mA) at a scan speed of 5° min-1. The fluorescence excitation and emission spectra were recorded at room temperature with a Hitachi F-4500 spectrophotometer equipped with a 150 W xenon lamp as an excitation source. Temperature-dependent magnetic measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS-7 magnetometer with an applied field of 1000 Oe. The diamagnetic corrections for the complexes were estimated using Pascal's constants and magnetic data were corrected for diamagnetic contributions of the sample holder.

elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of H3L Ligand and Observed Coordination Modes in Complexes 1-6

elements.content: The X-ray intensity data for the six complexes were collected on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å, 45 kV, 35 mA). The crystal structure was solved by means of direct methods and refined employing full-matrix least-squares on F 2 (SHELXTL-97). All the hydrogen atoms except for those of guest water molecules were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model. The hydrogen atoms of disordered guest molecules for complexes 3–5 were not included in the model, since they could not be found in the Fourier maps and fixed in the ideal position. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The “isor” command has been used in the refinement of 3 (O4), 4 (C12, C13, C15, C16, O6, O13, O14, O7w), 5 (C27, C28, C29, C30, N4), and 6 (C26, C27, C29, C30). The disordered O atom of complex 5 (O3w, O3w′) was refined using O atoms split over two sites, with a total occupancy of 1. The lattice water molecules were determined with the XRD data, combined with Platon, elemental analysis, and TGA data. Crystal data and details of the structure determination for complexes 1–6 are listed in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The X-ray intensity data for the six complexes were collected on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å, 45 kV, 35 mA). The crystal structure was solved by means of direct methods and refined employing full-matrix least-squares on F 2 (SHELXTL-97). All the hydrogen atoms except for those of guest water molecules were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model. The hydrogen atoms of disordered guest molecules for complexes 3-5 were not included in the model, since they could not be found in the Fourier maps and fixed in the ideal position. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The "isor" command has been used in the refinement of 3 (O4), 4 (C12, C13, C15, C16, O6, O13, O14, O7w), 5 (C27, C28, C29, C30, N4), and 6 (C26, C27, C29, C30). The disordered O atom of complex 5 (O3w, O3w') was refined using O atoms split over two sites, with a total occupancy of 1. The lattice water molecules were determined with the XRD data, combined with Platon, elemental analysis, and TGA data. Crystal data and details of the structure determination for complexes 1-6 are listed in Table .

Single-crystal X-ray analysis of 1 and 2 indicate that they are isostructural. The structure of complex 1 is described in detail here as a representative example. Complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit contains one and a half crystallographically independent zinc ions, one L3– ligand, a half bix molecule, one aqua ligand, and one lattice water molecule. As shown in Figure a, the central Zn2 ion is located at the crystallographic inversion center and is six-coordinated by six oxygen atoms from six different carboxylate groups to finish a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The terminal Zn1 ion has a distorted square-pyramid coordination environment provided by one nitrogen atom from the neutral bix ligand, four oxygen atoms from three carboxylate groups, and one aqua ligand. The Zn–O distances range from 2.0250(15) Å to 2.1717(17) Å, and the Zn–N distance is 2.0983(19) Å. Interestingly, though Zn1 and O2 are not bonded, the distance between Zn1 and O2 [2.5582(19) Å], which is shorter than the van der Waals radii of Zn and O (2.90 Å), indicates a weak secondary bonding. This phenomenon could be owing to the distortion of the Zn square-pyramid geometry and the twist spatial structure of L3–. The central Zn2 ion is linked to two symmetry-related terminal Zn ions by six carboxylate groups in μ 2 -η2 and syn-syn-μ 2 -η1:η1 coordination modes (Scheme b) to afford a linear Zn3 core with a Zn···Zn distance of 3.4790(3) Å (Figure a).

Single-crystal X-ray analysis of 1 and 2 indicate that they are isostructural. The structure of complex 1 is described in detail here as a representative example. Complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit contains one and a half crystallographically independent zinc ions, one L3- ligand, a half bix molecule, one aqua ligand, and one lattice water molecule. As shown in Figure a, the central Zn2 ion is located at the crystallographic inversion center and is six-coordinated by six oxygen atoms from six different carboxylate groups to finish a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The terminal Zn1 ion has a distorted square-pyramid coordination environment provided by one nitrogen atom from the neutral bix ligand, four oxygen atoms from three carboxylate groups, and one aqua ligand. The Zn-O distances range from 2.0250(15) Å to 2.1717(17) Å, and the Zn-N distance is 2.0983(19) Å. Interestingly, though Zn1 and O2 are not bonded, the distance between Zn1 and O2 [2.5582(19) Å], which is shorter than the van der Waals radii of Zn and O (2.90 Å), indicates a weak secondary bonding. This phenomenon could be owing to the distortion of the Zn square-pyramid geometry and the twist spatial structure of L3-. The central Zn2 ion is linked to two symmetry-related terminal Zn ions by six carboxylate groups in μ 2 -η2 and syn-syn-μ 2 -η1:η1 coordination modes (Scheme b) to afford a linear Zn3 core with a Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 3.4790(3) Å (Figure a).

elements.content: To better understand this intricate three-dimensional framework based on trinuclear secondary building units, the topological approach is necessary. The L3– ligand can be reduced to a 3-connected node, as each L3– anion connects with three trinuclear moieties. The bix ligand, which can be considered as a linear linker, connect with two trinuclear moieties. In turn, the trinuclear SBUs can be defined as an eight-connected node, connecting with six L3– anions and linking to two trinuclear moieties by two linear linkers (Figure a). So the whole framework possesses a (3,8)-connected tfz-d type topology calculated by TOPOS. From another point of view, the trinuclear moieties are linked by L3– ligands to generate 2D layers in the ac plane with dangling nitro groups (Figure b). The dihedral angle between the two benzene rings of the semirigid V-shaped ligand is 88.863(79)°. Further, the adjacent layers are interlinked by the bix ligand to form the 3D framework (Figure e) with the Schläfli symbol of {43}2{46·618·84}. It is worth noting that there are strong π–π interactions between the adjacent benzene planes of the L3– ligand within the 2D layer with the centroid–centroid distances of 3.5007(1) Å and 3.5891(1) Å, between two nearly parallel benzene rings, respectively (Figure , panels c and d). In addition, the presence of aqua ligands and lattice water molecules leads to the formation of extensive H-bonding interactions [H···O(1w) = 1.8184(349) Å, O(1w)···O(10) = 2.6637(25) Å, ∠OHO = 173.111(3968)°], which increases the stability of the whole framework.

elements.content: When the 4,4′-bpy ligand was utilized in place of bix ligand under appropriate reaction conditions, compound 3 was obtained. It was also solved in the triclinic space group P1̅ with three Co(II) ions, two L3– ligands, three 4,4′-bpy molecules, and four and a half lattice water molecules in the asymmetric unit. As depicted in Figure a, the terminal Co1 and Co2 ions exhibit similar coordination environments, which are completed by four oxygen atoms provided by three different L3– anions, and two nitrogen atoms from two 4,4′-bpy ligands, thus representing the Co{O4N2} distorted octahedral geometry. The Co3 ion also displays distorted octahedral geometry, but with CoO6 moieties, in which all of oxygen atoms are provided by different carboxylate groups. The Co–O distances range from 2.006(50) to 2.378(15) Å, and the Co–N distances range from 2.099(16) to 2.128(50) Å. Co1 is linked to Co3 via three carboxylate groups, and Co3 is also linked to Co2 via three carboxylate groups, forming a nonlinear trinuclear Co cluster (Figure b). There are two different L3– ligands in complex 3, which showed a different coordinated motif (Scheme a) so that the Co3 ion is not located at the crystallographic inversion center as the Zn2 atom of 1. However, the dihedral angle [82.425(343)°, 85.968(343)°] between the two benzene rings of the ligand are also very large; the 2D layer similar to that of complex 1 is formed (Figure c). Additionally, the adjacent layers are interlinked by one type of 4,4′-bpy ligands to form a 3D framework (Figure d).

When the 4,4'-bpy ligand was utilized in place of bix ligand under appropriate reaction conditions, compound 3 was obtained. It was also solved in the triclinic space group P1̅ with three Co(II) ions, two L3- ligands, three 4,4'-bpy molecules, and four and a half lattice water molecules in the asymmetric unit. As depicted in Figure a, the terminal Co1 and Co2 ions exhibit similar coordination environments, which are completed by four oxygen atoms provided by three different L3- anions, and two nitrogen atoms from two 4,4'-bpy ligands, thus representing the Co{O4N2} distorted octahedral geometry. The Co3 ion also displays distorted octahedral geometry, but with CoO6 moieties, in which all of oxygen atoms are provided by different carboxylate groups. The Co-O distances range from 2.006(50) to 2.378(15) Å, and the Co-N distances range from 2.099(16) to 2.128(50) Å. Co1 is linked to Co3 via three carboxylate groups, and Co3 is also linked to Co2 via three carboxylate groups, forming a nonlinear trinuclear Co cluster (Figure b). There are two different L3- ligands in complex 3, which showed a different coordinated motif (Scheme a) so that the Co3 ion is not located at the crystallographic inversion center as the Zn2 atom of 1. However, the dihedral angle [82.425(343)°, 85.968(343)°] between the two benzene rings of the ligand are also very large; the 2D layer similar to that of complex 1 is formed (Figure c). Additionally, the adjacent layers are interlinked by one type of 4,4'-bpy ligands to form a 3D framework (Figure d).

elements.content: From comparisons of its structure with complex 1, there are two considerable points which need to be described in detail. First, the 4,4′-bpy ligands in complex 3 are instead both the bix ligands and the aqua ligands in complex 1. Therefore, the 4,4′-bpy ligand can be treated as a linear linker like the bix ligand and terminal ligand like the aqua ligand. The bix ligand displays a Z type, since it is more flexible, otherwise the 4,4′-bpy ligand is a linear and rigid ligand. Considering the difference between two neutral ligands, we speculate that the Z-type bix ligand hinders further reaction with the Co(II) ion to develop into a 3D structure; however, the 4,4′-bpy ligand can not only instead of the bix ligand but also instead of the aqua ligand generate a new 3D MOF, owing to its smaller steric hindrance. Second, the Zn3 core cluster is symmetrical and linear; however, the Co3 core cluster is antisymmetrical and nonlinear. This can be presumed from the sterically hindered change caused by different neutral ligands.

elements.content: Complex 4 crystallizes in the triclinic system with a P1̅ space group. Analysis of the single crystal X-ray diffraction data indicates that the asymmetric unit of 4 consists of three crystallographically distinct Cd(II) ions, two L3– ligands, and three 4,4′-bpy molecules, as shown in Figure a. The central Cd1 ion has a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry with six oxygen atoms from six L3– ligands. The Cd3 ion is five coordinated by three oxygen atoms from three different L3– ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two 4,4′-bpy molecules to finish a distorted trigonal bipyramid coordination geometry. Cd2 is also five-coordinated by three oxygen atoms from three different L3– ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two 4,4′-bpy molecules but to form a distorted square-pyramid coordination geometry (Figure a). It should be noted that although O2 and O11 are not coordinated to Cd2, and O16 is not coordinated to Cd3, the bond distances of Cd2···O2 [2.639(3) Å], Cd2···O11 [2.687(4) Å], and Cd3···O16 [2.655(3) Å] are shorter than the sum of the van der Walls radii (3.08 Å), which indicate a weak secondary bonding. This phenomenon may contribute to the distortion of the Cd trigonal bipyramid and square-pyramid geometry and result in the variation of coordination environments. The 3D framework of complex 4 is the same as complex 3, thus it will not be characterized in detail.

elements.content: Compared with the complex 3, L3– exhibits different coordination modes: μ 2 -η2 and syn-syn-μ 2 -η1:η1 coordination modes (Scheme b). This leads to the formation of the unprecedented trinuclear Cd cluster with two five-coordinated Cd(II) ions and one six-coordinated Cd(II) ions. To the best of our knowledge, the trinuclear Cd cluster is very unusual.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of complex 5 consists of one and a half crystallographically independent Cu(II) ions, one L3– ligand, one and a half 4,4′-bpy molecules, and it also belongs to the triclinic system with a P1̅ space group. As depicted in Figure a, the central Cu1 ion is located at the crystallographic inversion center and is four-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from four different carboxylate groups to build a distorted square planar coordination geometry. Cu2 is five-coordinated by three oxygen atoms from three different L3– ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two 4,4′-bpy molecules to form a distorted square-pyramid coordination geometry. The Cu–O distances range from 1.9175(60) to 2.190(60) Å, and the Cu–N distances range from 2.018(7) Å to 2.028(7) Å. Similar to complex 4, the distances of Cu1···O8 2.5232(61) Å and Cu2···O9 2.6739(69) Å which are shorter than the sum of the van der Walls radii (2.92 Å) indicate a weak interaction between the O and Cu atoms. This phenomenon may be ascribed to the distortion of the Cu square-pyramid geometry and result in the variation of coordination environments. The 3D framework of complex 5 is also the same as complex 3 and will not be described in detail.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 6 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit contains one and a half crystallographically independent Ni(II) ions, one L3– ligand, one and a half 4,4′-bpy molecules, three aqua ligands, and two lattice water molecules. As depicted in Figure a, one motif is a 2D anionic [Ni(L)(4,4′-bpy)(H2O)]∞ –, in which Ni1 is octahedrally coordinated by four oxygen atoms from one chelating bidentate carboxylate group [Ni–O = 2.098(2) – 2.140(2) Å], one monodentate-bridging carboxylate group [Ni–O = 2.021(2) Å], one terminal aqua ligand [Ni–O = 2.076(2) Å], and two nitrogen atoms from two 4,4′-bpy molecules [Ni–N = 2.079(3)-2.105(3) Å]. In the 1D cationic motif [Ni0.5(4,4′-bpy)0.5(H2O)2]∞ +, Ni2 is coordinated by four aqua ligands [Ni–O = 2.020(2) – 2.101(3) Å] in the equatorial plane and two 4,4′-bpy ligands [Ni–N = 2.111(3) Å] in the axial position (Figure b).

Structure of {[Ni1.5(L)(4,4'-bpy)1.5(H2O)3]⋅2H2O} n  (6)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 6 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit contains one and a half crystallographically independent Ni(II) ions, one L3- ligand, one and a half 4,4'-bpy molecules, three aqua ligands, and two lattice water molecules. As depicted in Figure a, one motif is a 2D anionic [Ni(L)(4,4'-bpy)(H2O)]∞ -, in which Ni1 is octahedrally coordinated by four oxygen atoms from one chelating bidentate carboxylate group [Ni-O = 2.098(2) - 2.140(2) Å], one monodentate-bridging carboxylate group [Ni-O = 2.021(2) Å], one terminal aqua ligand [Ni-O = 2.076(2) Å], and two nitrogen atoms from two 4,4'-bpy molecules [Ni-N = 2.079(3)-2.105(3) Å]. In the 1D cationic motif [Ni0.5(4,4'-bpy)0.5(H2O)2]∞ +, Ni2 is coordinated by four aqua ligands [Ni-O = 2.020(2) - 2.101(3) Å] in the equatorial plane and two 4,4'-bpy ligands [Ni-N = 2.111(3) Å] in the axial position (Figure b).

elements.content: To deeply understand the structure of this framework, it would be important to explore the connected modes of the metal centers and organic ligands. The feature of the cationic motif is easily understand, in which the metal center Ni2 and 4,4′-bpy ligands form a 1D chain structure along the b axis. For the anionic motif, the linkage of the L3– anions, 4,4′-bpy, and the Ni1 centers affords a (4,4)-connected layer parallel to the ab plane (Figure , panels c and d). Along the c direction, adjacent sheets are packed parallel in a ···ABAB··· fashion. Different from the previously similar complex reported by Duan and co-workers, a series of 1D chains are almost parallel to the 2D sheets and cannot pass through the 2D sheets, owing to the steric hindrance of the phenyl rings (Figure , panels c and d). Further, the 1D chains and the 2D sheets are connected into a 3D intricate network via hydrogen-bonding interactions (Figure S2 of the ).
elements.clean_text: To deeply understand the structure of this framework, it would be important to explore the connected modes of the metal centers and organic ligands. The feature of the cationic motif is easily understand, in which the metal center Ni2 and 4,4'-bpy ligands form a 1D chain structure along the b axis. For the anionic motif, the linkage of the L3- anions, 4,4'-bpy, and the Ni1 centers affords a (4,4)-connected layer parallel to the ab plane (Figure , panels c and d). Along the c direction, adjacent sheets are packed parallel in a ⋅⋅⋅ABAB⋅⋅⋅ fashion. Different from the previously similar complex reported by Duan and co-workers, a series of 1D chains are almost parallel to the 2D sheets and cannot pass through the 2D sheets, owing to the steric hindrance of the phenyl rings (Figure , panels c and d). Further, the 1D chains and the 2D sheets are connected into a 3D intricate network via hydrogen-bonding interactions (Figure S2 of the ).

elements.content: It is notable that the framework of complex 6 is completely different from the former five complexes. In complex 6, only two carboxylate groups of the L3– ligand participate in coordination with one η1:η1 and one η1 coordination motif (Scheme d), so the L3– ligand is used as the 2-connected ligand to construct the (4,4)-connected layer. The uncoordinated carboxylated group and the phenyl rings twist in the quadrilateral due to the large dihedral angle [84.190(142)°] of the two phenyl rings. Some similar compounds have been reported by other groups in which the 1D chains of the compounds all pass through 2D sheets. However, the 1D chains of complex 6 almost parallel to the 2D sheets, which is worthy of attention.

elements.content: In complexes 1–5, the tricarboxylate ligands adopt η1, μ 2 -η2, μ 2 -η 2 :η1, and syn-syn-μ 2 -η1:η1 coordination modes, which links metal atoms to form trinuclear metal units. In complex 6, the tricarboxylate ligands adopt η1 and η1:η1 coordination modes with only two carboxylate groups, which lead the metal atoms to form isolated mononuclear motifs. Therefore, the coordination modes of the carboxylate ligands are primarily responsible for the structural diversity of the complexes. Furthermore, the N-containing auxiliary ligands varied in the assembly process are also important for the terminal structures of the complexes. Interestingly, for complexes 1–5, all of them are constructed through the trinuclear SBUs and L3– to form a 2D layer, then pillared by 4,4′-bpy and bix ligands to complete the 3D frameworks. In this regard, the semirigid V-shaped tricarboxylate ligand is a good candidate to construct varieties of 3D frameworks.

elements.content: The luminescent properties of carboxylate containing system with d10 metal centers have been investigated widely and can be applied as photoactive materials, chemical probes, and cation-induced photoswitches. The luminescent properties of the free ligand as well as complexes 1 and 4 are investigated in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , the maximum emission wavelength of the free H3L ligand is at 424 nm, which is excited at 212 nm. For complexes 1 and 4, the luminescent spectrum exhibits a broad band with the maximum peak observed at 469 nm, exciting at 207 nm. Since the Zn2+ and Cd2+ ions are difficult to oxidize or to reduce for their d10 configuration, the emissions of both complexes are neither the metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). It can probably be assigned to the π–π* intraligand fluorescence due to their close resemblance to the emission bonds.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

The luminescent properties of carboxylate containing system with d10 metal centers have been investigated widely and can be applied as photoactive materials, chemical probes, and cation-induced photoswitches. The luminescent properties of the free ligand as well as complexes 1 and 4 are investigated in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , the maximum emission wavelength of the free H3L ligand is at 424 nm, which is excited at 212 nm. For complexes 1 and 4, the luminescent spectrum exhibits a broad band with the maximum peak observed at 469 nm, exciting at 207 nm. Since the Zn2+ and Cd2+ ions are difficult to oxidize or to reduce for their d10 configuration, the emissions of both complexes are neither the metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). It can probably be assigned to the π-π* intraligand fluorescence due to their close resemblance to the emission bonds.

elements.content: As shown in Figures and , the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibilities of complexes 2 and 3 are displayed in the form of χM –1 and χM T versus T plots from 2 to 300 K with an applied field of 1000 Oe. The experimental χM T values of 2 and 3 at room temperature are 10.05 cm3 mol–1 K and 10.56 cm3 mol–1 K, respectively, which are slightly larger than the spin value expected for three uncoupled high-spin Co(II) ions (5.63 cm3 mol–1 K), owing to a large orbital contribution of the high-spin octahedral Co(II) centers. The inverse susceptibility plot as a function of temperature is linear above 35 K, following the Curie–Weiss law with a Weiss constants of θ = −24.90 K for 2 and −24.36 K for 3. Curie constants are 10.89 and 11.39 cm3 mol–1 K for 2 and 3, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Studies

As shown in Figures  and , the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibilities of complexes 2 and 3 are displayed in the form of χM -1 and χM T versus T plots from 2 to 300 K with an applied field of 1000 Oe. The experimental χM T values of 2 and 3 at room temperature are 10.05 cm3 mol-1 K and 10.56 cm3 mol-1 K, respectively, which are slightly larger than the spin value expected for three uncoupled high-spin Co(II) ions (5.63 cm3 mol-1 K), owing to a large orbital contribution of the high-spin octahedral Co(II) centers. The inverse susceptibility plot as a function of temperature is linear above 35 K, following the Curie-Weiss law with a Weiss constants of θ = -24.90 K for 2 and -24.36 K for 3. Curie constants are 10.89 and 11.39 cm3 mol-1 K for 2 and 3, respectively.

elements.content: For 2, the χM T value decreases smoothly to a minimum value of 5.04 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K with decreasing temperature. The moderate negative θ values and the total decrease of χM T indicate the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions between adjacent Co(II) ions, even if a contribution from the spin–orbit coupling of Co(II) is also present. For 3, the χM T curves shows similar diversification at high temperature. It decreases continuously with decreasing temperature and reaches a minimum value of 6.97 cm3 mol–1 K at 14 K, resulting from the depopulation of the higher energy Kramers doublets associated with the high-spin Co(II) single ions, which indicates an antiferromagnetic coupling among the Co(II) ions. Upon further cooling, the χM T value increases rapidly up to a maximum of 9.05 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K, which may arise from ferromagnetic interactions between the units. The variant magnetic properties for complexes 2 and 3 are mainly caused by the different forms of connection between the units.

elements.content: The IR spectrum of complex 1 shows characteristic strong bands of the carboxylate groups at 1620 and 1527 cm–1 and 1381 cm–1 for the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations, respectively. The separations (Δ) between v asym (CO2) and v sym (CO2) are at 239 and 146 cm–1, respectively. Similar values are found for complexes 2–6, so the detailed information is shown in Table S1 (). The splitting of v asym (CO2) in each complex indicates that the L3– carboxylate groups function in two different coordination fashions, consistent with the crystal structures of 1–6.
elements.clean_text:
Infrared Spectroscopy

The IR spectrum of complex 1 shows characteristic strong bands of the carboxylate groups at 1620 and 1527 cm-1 and 1381 cm-1 for the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations, respectively. The separations (Δ) between v asym (CO2) and v sym (CO2) are at 239 and 146 cm-1, respectively. Similar values are found for complexes 2-6, so the detailed information is shown in Table S1 (). The splitting of v asym (CO2) in each complex indicates that the L3- carboxylate groups function in two different coordination fashions, consistent with the crystal structures of 1-6.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction experiments were carried out for all six complexes. The patterns for the as-synthesized bulk materials closely match the simulated ones from the single-crystal structure analysis, which are indicative of the pure solid-state phases (Figures S5–S10 of the ). Thermogravimetric analyses were also investigated for all six complexes to investigate their thermal decomposition behaviors (Figure S11 of the ).
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis and PXRD Results

Powder X-ray diffraction experiments were carried out for all six complexes. The patterns for the as-synthesized bulk materials closely match the simulated ones from the single-crystal structure analysis, which are indicative of the pure solid-state phases (Figures S5-S10 of the ). Thermogravimetric analyses were also investigated for all six complexes to investigate their thermal decomposition behaviors (Figure S11 of the ).

elements.content: Complex 1 is stable up to 100 °C, and then the lattice water molecules and coordinated water molecules are released (obsd 4.85%, calcd 6.03%). No further weight loss was observed until 290 °C and followed by the backbone decomposition at around 400 °C. The final mass remnant is roughly consistent with a deposition of ZnO (obsd 18.55%, calcd 20.43%).

The remaining substance is stable to 400 °C, and further weight loss is observed at about 410 °C, due to the decomposition of the overall framework along with the loss of the L3– and bix ligands (obsd 75.73%, calcd 74.75%).

elements.content: Complex 3 shows a weight loss of about 4.04% from room temperature to 150 °C, which is attributed to the loss of the lattice water molecules (calcd 6.32%). No further weight loss was observed until 330 °C, at which point the complex begins to decompose. The final mass remnant is consistent with a deposition of CoO (obsd 15.72%, calcd 15.89%).

elements.content: For complex 5, the first weight loss of 9.56% corresponds to the loss of three lattice water molecules (calcd 7.43%) from room temperature to 180 °C. The decomposition process is followed by a plateau of stability from 180 to 295 °C, and then the framework rapidly collapses. The observed final mass remnant of 14.58% likely represents deposition of CuO, which agrees with the calculated value of 16.39%.

The network of complex 6 started to decompose when the temperature was higher than 310 °C. The remaining weight corresponded to the formation of NiO (obsd 16.68%, calcd 14.81%).

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully synthesized six metal–organic frameworks assembling by the semirigid V-shaped ligand, two neutral ligands, and different metal ions under suitable hydrothermal conditions. The results illustrate that the coordination modes of the carboxylate ligands and the coordination behaviors of metal ions play important roles in the construction of coordination polymers and meanwhile indicate that the neutral ligand could affect the formation of the final architecture. It is believed that the initiatory research assembled in crystal engineering of functional metal–organic frameworks based on the semirigid V-shaped tricarboxylate ligands would lead to novel coordination polymers with interesting structures and properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have successfully synthesized six metal-organic frameworks assembling by the semirigid V-shaped ligand, two neutral ligands, and different metal ions under suitable hydrothermal conditions. The results illustrate that the coordination modes of the carboxylate ligands and the coordination behaviors of metal ions play important roles in the construction of coordination polymers and meanwhile indicate that the neutral ligand could affect the formation of the final architecture. It is believed that the initiatory research assembled in crystal engineering of functional metal-organic frameworks based on the semirigid V-shaped tricarboxylate ligands would lead to novel coordination polymers with interesting structures and properties.

cln_elements.content:
Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 6 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit contains one and a half crystallographically independent Ni(II) ions, one L3– ligand, one and a half 4,4′-bpy molecules, three aqua ligands, and two lattice water molecules. As depicted in Figure a, one motif is a 2D anionic [Ni(L)(4,4′-bpy)(H2O)]∞ –, in which Ni1 is octahedrally coordinated by four oxygen atoms from one chelating bidentate carboxylate group [Ni–O = 2.098(2) – 2.140(2) Å], one monodentate-bridging carboxylate group [Ni–O = 2.021(2) Å], one terminal aqua ligand [Ni–O = 2.076(2) Å], and two nitrogen atoms from two 4,4′-bpy molecules [Ni–N = 2.079(3)-2.105(3) Å]. In the 1D cationic motif [Ni0.5(4,4′-bpy)0.5(H2O)2]∞ +, Ni2 is coordinated by four aqua ligands [Ni–O = 2.020(2) – 2.101(3) Å] in the equatorial plane and two 4,4′-bpy ligands [Ni–N = 2.111(3) Å] in the axial position (Figure b).

Photoluminescent Properties

The luminescent properties of carboxylate containing system with d10 metal centers have been investigated widely and can be applied as photoactive materials, chemical probes, and cation-induced photoswitches. The luminescent properties of the free ligand as well as complexes 1 and 4 are investigated in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , the maximum emission wavelength of the free H3L ligand is at 424 nm, which is excited at 212 nm. For complexes 1 and 4, the luminescent spectrum exhibits a broad band with the maximum peak observed at 469 nm, exciting at 207 nm. Since the Zn2+ and Cd2+ ions are difficult to oxidize or to reduce for their d10 configuration, the emissions of both complexes are neither the metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). It can probably be assigned to the π–π* intraligand fluorescence due to their close resemblance to the emission bonds.

Magnetic Studies

As shown in Figures and , the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibilities of complexes 2 and 3 are displayed in the form of χM –1 and χM T versus T plots from 2 to 300 K with an applied field of 1000 Oe. The experimental χM T values of 2 and 3 at room temperature are 10.05 cm3 mol–1 K and 10.56 cm3 mol–1 K, respectively, which are slightly larger than the spin value expected for three uncoupled high-spin Co(II) ions (5.63 cm3 mol–1 K), owing to a large orbital contribution of the high-spin octahedral Co(II) centers. The inverse susceptibility plot as a function of temperature is linear above 35 K, following the Curie–Weiss law with a Weiss constants of θ = −24.90 K for 2 and −24.36 K for 3. Curie constants are 10.89 and 11.39 cm3 mol–1 K for 2 and 3, respectively.

Complex 1 is stable up to 100 °C, and then the lattice water molecules and coordinated water molecules are released (obsd 4.85%, calcd 6.03%). No further weight loss was observed until 290 °C and followed by the backbone decomposition at around 400 °C. The final mass remnant is roughly consistent with a deposition of ZnO (obsd 18.55%, calcd 20.43%).

In the case of complex 2, the first weight loss of 7.00% (calcd 6.13%) in the range of 120–180 °C corresponds to the removal of one coordinated and one lattice water molecules. The remaining substance is stable to 400 °C, and further weight loss is observed at about 410 °C, due to the decomposition of the overall framework along with the loss of the L3– and bix ligands (obsd 75.73%, calcd 74.75%).

Complex 3 shows a weight loss of about 4.04% from room temperature to 150 °C, which is attributed to the loss of the lattice water molecules (calcd 6.32%). No further weight loss was observed until 330 °C, at which point the complex begins to decompose. The final mass remnant is consistent with a deposition of CoO (obsd 15.72%, calcd 15.89%).

Complex 4 is stable up to 230 °C, and then the lattice water molecules are released (obsd 5.26%, calcd 5.14%), immediately followed by the backbone decomposition at around 250 °C. The final mass remnant is roughly consistent with a deposition of CdO (obsd 21.03%, calcd 24.46%).

For complex 5, the first weight loss of 9.56% corresponds to the loss of three lattice water molecules (calcd 7.43%) from room temperature to 180 °C. The decomposition process is followed by a plateau of stability from 180 to 295 °C, and then the framework rapidly collapses. The observed final mass remnant of 14.58% likely represents deposition of CuO, which agrees with the calculated value of 16.39%.

The TGA curve of complex 6 showed a weight loss of 8.68% in the range of 76–210 °C, which was attributed to the release of part of the lattice water molecules and the aqua ligands in the network. The network of complex 6 started to decompose when the temperature was higher than 310 °C. The remaining weight corresponded to the formation of NiO (obsd 16.68%, calcd 14.81%).
